My child’s voice makes it difficult for people to hear him/her.

People ask my child to repeat him/herself when speaking face-to-face.
My child’s voice difficulties restrict personal, educational and social activities.

My child is frustrated with his/her voice problem

question.en: Category 1 - Parkinsonism
Category 2 - Exclusion criteria

name.en: Diagnosis of behavioral variant of frontotemporal dementia or primary progressive aphasia within 5 years of disease onset
Parkinsonian features restricted to the lower limbs for more than 3 years
Treatment with a dopamine receptor blocker or dopamine depleting agent consistent with drug-induced parkinsonism
Absence of a response to high-dose levodopa despite at least moderate disease severity
Cortical sensory loss, clear limb ideomotor apraxia, or progressive aphasia
Normal functional imaging of the dopaminergic system ("DAT scan")
Diagnosis of alternative condition causing parkinsonism which could be causing the symptoms

question.en: Category 3 - Supportive criteria

name.en: Clear beneficial response to dopaminergic therapy
The presence of either olfactory loss or cardiac sympathetic denervation on MIBG scintigraphy (although the latter is rarely done in current practice)

difficulty_concentrating.description: Indicates if the participant has difficulty concentrating.

question.en: How often do you have difficulty concentrating on what people say to you, even when they are speaking to you directly?

misplace.description: Indicates if the participant often misplaces things.

question.en: How often do you misplace or have difficulty finding things at home or at work?

distracted.description: Indicates if the participant feels distracted during the session.

question.en: How often are you distracted by activity or noise around you?

remain_seated.description: Indicates if the participant is able to remain seated for long periods.

question.en: How often do you leave your seat in meetings or other situations in which you are expected to remain seated?

restless.description: Indicates if the participant feels restless.

question.en: How often do you feel restless or fidgety?

difficulty_unwinding.description: Indicates if the participant has difficulty unwinding or relaxing after stressful events.

question.en: How often do you have difficulty unwinding and relaxing when you have time to yourself?

talking_too_much.description: Indicates if the participant feels they are talking too much.

question.en: How often do you find yourself talking too much when you are in social situations?

finish_other_sent.description: Indicates if the participant finishes others' sentences.

question.en: When you're in a conversation, how often do you find yourself finishing the sentences of the people you are talking to, before they can finish them themselves?

difficulty_waiting.description: Indicates if the participant has difficulty waiting for others.

question.en: How often do you have difficulty waiting your turn in situations when turn taking is required?

interrupt_others.description: Indicates if the participant tends to interrupt others during conversations.

question.en: How often do you interrupt others when they are busy?

question.en: Number of questions asked

winograd_questions_asked.description: The total number of Winograd questions asked during the session.

question.en:
Questions asked
(Comma separated)

winograd_q_1.description: Response to Winograd question 1: 'Can the participant interpret social dynamics based on context?'

question.en: 1. The city councilmen refused the demonstrators a permit because they feared violence. Who feared violence?

winograd_q_2.description: Response to Winograd question 2: 'Can the participant interpret the outcome of an ambiguous scenario?'

question.en: 2. The city councilmen refused the demonstrators a permit because they advocated violence. Who advocated violence?

winograd_q_3.description: Response to Winograd question 3: 'Can the participant infer the intentions of others based on contextual clues?'

question.en: 3. The trophy doesn't fit into the brown suitcase because it's too small. What is too small?

winograd_q_4.description: Response to Winograd question 4: 'Can the participant resolve ambiguity in a situation involving social dynamics?'

question.en: 4. The trophy doesn't fit into the brown suitcase because it's too large. What is too large?

winograd_q_5.description: Response to Winograd question 5: 'Can the participant make inferences about an agent's actions based on context?'

question.en: 5. Joan made sure to thank Susan for all the help she had given. Who had given help?

winograd_q_6.description: Response to Winograd question 6: 'Can the participant reason about an everyday scenario involving multiple agents?'

question.en: 6. Joan made sure to thank Susan for all the help she had received. Who had received help?

winograd_q_7.description: Response to Winograd question 7: 'Can the participant make logical inferences about everyday situations?'

question.en: 7. Paul tried to call George on the phone, but he wasn't successful. Who was not successful?

winograd_q_8.description: Response to Winograd question 8: 'Can the participant infer the correct outcome in a scenario involving social dynamics?'

question.en: 8. Paul tried to call George on the phone, but he wasn't available. Who was not available?

winograd_q_9.description: Response to Winograd question 9: 'Does the participant understand cause and effect relationships in social interactions?'

question.en: 9. The lawyer asked the witness a question, but he was reluctant to answer it. Who was reluctant to answer the question?

winograd_q_10.description: Response to Winograd question 10: 'Can the participant infer the correct outcome in a scenario involving social dynamics?'

question.en: 10. The lawyer asked the witness a question, but he was reluctant to repeat it. Who was reluctant to repeat the question?

winograd_q_11.description: Response to Winograd question 11: 'Can the participant infer the correct outcome based on reasoning?'

question.en: 11. The delivery truck zoomed by the school bus because it was going so fast. What was going so fast?

winograd_q_12.description: Response to Winograd question 12: 'Can the participant infer the intentions of others based on context?'

question.en: 12. The delivery truck zoomed by the school bus because it was going so slow. What was going so slow?

winograd_q_13.description: Response to Winograd question 13: 'Can the participant reason about the effects of actions in a social scenario?'

question.en: 13. Frank felt vindicated when his longtime rival Bill revealed that he was the winner of the competition. Who was the winner of the competition?

winograd_q_14.description: Response to Winograd question 14: 'Can the participant resolve ambiguity in a scenario involving multiple agents?'

question.en: 14. Frank felt crushed when his longtime rival Bill revealed that he was the winner of the competition. Who was the winner of the competition?

winograd_q_15.description: Response to Winograd question 15: 'Can the participant reason through cause and effect in a social scenario?'

question.en: 15. The man couldn't lift his son because he was so weak. Who was weak?

winograd_q_16.description: Response to Winograd question 16: 'Can the participant make logical inferences about cause and effect in a scenario?'

question.en: 16. The man couldn't lift his son because he was so heavy. Who was heavy?

winograd_q_17.description: Response to Winograd question 17: 'Can the participant infer the correct outcome in a scenario involving multiple agents?'

question.en: 17. The large ball crashed right through the table because it was made of steel. What was made of steel?

winograd_q_18.description: Response to Winograd question 18: 'Can the participant use common sense reasoning to infer the outcome of a situation?'

question.en: 18. The large ball crashed right through the table because it was made of styrofoam. What was made of styrofoam?

winograd_q_19.description: Response to Winograd question 19: 'Does the participant demonstrate the ability to understand cause and effect in a scenario?'

question.en: 19. John couldn't see the stage with Billy in front of him because he is so short. Who is so short?

winograd_q_20.description: Response to Winograd question 20: 'Can the participant reason through social interactions in a scenario involving multiple agents?'

question.en: 20.  John couldn't see the stage with Billy in front of him because he is so tall. Who is so tall?

winograd_q_21.description: Response to Winograd question 21: 'Can the participant reason through the effects of actions in a social scenario?'

question.en: 21. Tom threw his schoolbag down to Ray after he reached the top of the stairs. Who reached the top of the stairs?

winograd_q_22.description: Response to Winograd question 22: 'Can the participant infer the correct outcome in a scenario involving multiple agents?'

question.en: 22. Tom threw his schoolbag down to Ray after he reached the bottom of the stairs. Who reached the bottom of the stairs?

winograd_q_23.description: Response to Winograd question 23: 'Can the participant reason about the intentions of others based on contextual clues?'

question.en: 23. Although they ran at about the same speed, Sue beat Sally because she had such a good start. Who had a good start?

winograd_q_24.description: Response to Winograd question 24: 'Can the participant reason about the consequences of actions in an ambiguous situation?'

question.en: 24. Although they ran at about the same speed, Sue beat Sally because she had such a bad start. Who had a bad start?

winograd_q_25.description: Response to Winograd question 25: 'Does the participant demonstrate an understanding of cause and effect in social situations?'

question.en: 25. The sculpture rolled off the shelf because it wasn't anchored. What wasn't anchored?

winograd_q_26.description: Response to Winograd question 26: 'Can the participant make inferences about social behaviors?'

question.en: 26. The sculpture rolled off the shelf because it wasn't level. What wasn't level?

winograd_q_27.description: Response to Winograd question 27: 'Can the participant make logical inferences about the actions of others in a scenario?'

question.en: 27. Sam's drawing was hung just above Tina's and it did look much better with another one below it. Which looked better?

winograd_q_28.description: Response to Winograd question 28: 'Can the participant reason logically about cause and effect?'

question.en: 28. Sam's drawing was hung just above Tina's and it did look much better with another one above it. Which looked better?

winograd_q_29.description: Response to Winograd question 29: 'Does the participant demonstrate common-sense reasoning in a social scenario?'

question.en: 29. Anna did a lot better than her good friend Lucy on the test because she had studied so hard. Who studied hard?

winograd_q_30.description: Response to Winograd question 30: 'Can the participant make logical deductions about social interactions?'

question.en: 30. Anna did a lot worse than her good friend Lucy on the test because she had studied so hard. Who studied hard?

winograd_q_31.description: Response to Winograd question 31: 'Does the participant understand logical cause and effect relationships?'

question.en: 31. The firemen arrived after the police because they were coming from so far away. Who came from far away?

winograd_q_32.description: Response to Winograd question 32: 'Can the participant recognize the logical outcomes of actions in social contexts?'

question.en: 32. The firemen arrived before the police because they were coming from so far away. Who came from far away?

winograd_q_33.description: Response to Winograd question 33: 'Can the participant infer the intentions of others based on contextual clues?'

question.en: 33. Frank was upset with Tom because the toaster he had bought from him didn't work. Who had bought the toaster?

winograd_q_34.description: Response to Winograd question 34: 'Can the participant infer the correct outcome in a scenario involving multiple agents?'

question.en: 34. Frank was upset with Tom because the toaster he had sold to him didn't work. Who had sold the toaster?

winograd_q_35.description: Response to Winograd question 35: 'Can the participant reason through social interactions in a scenario involving multiple agents?'

question.en: 35. Jim yelled at Kevin because he was so upset. Who was upset?

winograd_q_36.description: Response to Winograd question 36: 'Does the participant demonstrate common-sense reasoning in a scenario involving multiple agents?'

question.en: 36. Jim comforted Kevin because he was so upset. Who was upset?

winograd_q_37.description: Response to Winograd question 37: 'Does the participant demonstrate common-sense reasoning in resolving ambiguity in a social situation?'

question.en: 37. The sack of potatoes had been placed above the bag of flour, so it had to be moved first. What had to be moved first?

winograd_q_38.description: Response to Winograd question 38: 'Can the participant make logical inferences about the intentions of others in a scenario?'

question.en: 38. The sack of potatoes had been placed below the bag of flour, so it had to be moved first. What had to be moved first?

winograd_q_39.description: Response to Winograd question 39: 'Can the participant identify logical outcomes in a given situation?'

question.en: 39. Pete envies Martin because he is very successful. Who is very successful?

winograd_q_40.description: Response to Winograd question 40: 'Can the participant make logical inferences about the actions of others in a social situation?'

question.en: 40. Pete envies Martin although he is very successful. Who is very successful?

winograd_q_41.description: Response to Winograd question 41: 'Can the participant reason through ambiguity in a social situation?'

question.en: 41. I was trying to balance the bottle upside down on the table, but I couldn't do it because it was so top-heavy. What was top-heavy?

winograd_q_42.description: Response to Winograd question 42: 'Can the participant infer the intentions of others based on contextual clues?'

question.en: 42. I was trying to balance the bottle upside down on the table, but I couldn't do it because it was so uneven. What was uneven?

winograd_q_43.description: Response to Winograd question 43: 'Can the participant resolve ambiguous references in a text?'

question.en: 43. I spread the cloth on the table in order to protect it. To protect what?

winograd_q_44.description: Response to Winograd question 44: 'Can the participant resolve ambiguity in an interpersonal situation?'

question.en: 44. I spread the cloth on the table in order to display it. To display what?

winograd_q_45.description: Response to Winograd question 45: 'Does the participant understand abstract social concepts?'

question.en: 45. The older students were bullying the younger ones, so we rescued them. Whom did we rescued?

winograd_q_46.description: Response to Winograd question 46: 'Can the participant reason through ambiguity in a scenario involving multiple agents?'

question.en: 46. The older students were bullying the younger ones, so we punished them. Whom did we punished?

winograd_q_47.description: Response to Winograd question 47: 'Can the participant infer the correct outcome in a scenario involving social dynamics?'

question.en: 47. I poured water from the bottle into the cup until it was full. What was full?

winograd_q_48.description: Response to Winograd question 48: 'Can the participant infer the correct outcome in a social situation involving multiple agents?'

question.en: 48. I poured water from the bottle into the cup until it was empty. What was empty?

winograd_q_50.description: Response to Winograd question 50: 'Can the participant make logical inferences about the actions of others in a hypothetical scenario?'

question.en: 50. Susan knows all about Ann's personal problems because she is indiscreet. Who is indiscreet?

winograd_q_51.description: Response to Winograd question 51: 'Can the participant reason about the consequences of an action in a hypothetical situation?'

question.en: 51. Susan knew that Ann's son had been in a car accident, so she told her about it. Who told the other about the accident?

winograd_q_52.description: Response to Winograd question 52: 'Can the participant make logical inferences about the actions of others in a social situation?'

question.en: 52. Susan knew that Ann's son had been in a car accident, because she told her about it. Who told the other about the accident?

winograd_q_53.description: Response to Winograd question 53: 'Can the participant infer an action based on contextual cues?'

question.en: 53. Joe's uncle can still beat him at tennis, even though he is 30 years older. Who is older?

winograd_q_54.description: Response to Winograd question 54: 'Does the participant demonstrate the ability to understand cause and effect in a hypothetical situation?'

question.en: 54. Joe's uncle can still beat him at tennis, even though he is 30 years younger. Who is younger?

question.en: 55. The police left the house and went into the garage, where they found the murder weapon. Where did they find the murder weapon?

question.en: Session ID
Questionnaire Duration (seconds)
How often have you been bothered by each of the following symptoms during the past two weeks? For each symptom select the answer that best describes how you have been feeling
Feeling down, depressed, irritable, or hopeless?
Little interest or pleasure in doing things?
Trouble falling asleep, staying asleep, or sleeping too much?
Poor appetite, weight loss, or overeating?
Feeling tired, or having little energy?
Feeling bad about yourself – or feeling that you are a failure, or that you have let yourself or your family down?
Trouble concentrating on things like school work, reading, or watching TV?
Moving or speaking so slowly that other people could have noticed? Or the opposite – being so fidgety or restless that you were moving around a lot more than usual?
Thoughts that you would be better off dead, or of hurting yourself in some way?

question.en: Questionnaire Duration (seconds)
Have you smoked at least 100 cigarettes in your entire life? (There are 20 cigarettes in a pack.)?
Do you now smoke cigarettes every day, some days, or not at all?
How old were you when you first started regular cigarette smoking?
Age:
If you have completely stopped smoking cigarettes, about how old were you when you stopped?
Age when you stopped smoking:
How many years have you or did you smoke cigarettes?
Number of years:
On average, how many cigarettes do you smoke per day now? (There are 20 cigarettes in a pack.)
Number of cigarettes per day:
On average, over the entire time that you smoked, how many cigarettes did you smoke each day? (There are 20 cigarettes in a pack.)
Number of cigarettes per day:
In the PAST THREE MONTHS, how often have you used marijuana (cannabis, pot, grass, hash, etc.)?

Have you ever used an electronic nicotine product, even one or two times?
(Electronic nicotine products include e- cigarettes, vape pens, hookah pens, personal vaporizers and mods, e-cigars, e-pipes, and e-hookahs.)
Do you now use electronic nicotine products?

flashbacks.description: Indicates if the participant experiences flashbacks to stressful or traumatic events.

question.en: Having "flashbacks", that is, you suddenly acted or felt as if a stressful experience from the past was happening all over again (for example, you reexperienced parts of a stressful experience by seeing, hearing, smelling, or physically feeling parts of the experience)?

emotionally_upset.description: Indicates if the participant feels emotionally upset during the session.

neg_emotional_state.description: Indicates if the participant is experiencing negative emotional states.

losing_interest.description: Indicates if the participant is losing interest in things they usually enjoy.

question.en: Losing interest in activities you used to enjoy before having a stressful experience?

super_alert.description: Indicates if the participant is highly alert during the session.

question.en: Being "super alert", on guard, or constantly on the lookout for danger?

feeling_jumpy.description: Indicates if the participant feels jumpy or anxious.

question.en: Feeling jumpy or easily startled when you hear an unexpected noise?

irritable.description: Indicates if the participant feels irritable or easily annoyed.

question.en: Being extremely irritable or angry to the point where you yelled at other people, got into fights, or destroyed things?

question.en: Session ID
Questionnaire Duration (seconds)

Please answer these questions based on what your child’s voice (your own voice if you are a teenage respondent) has been like over the last 2 weeks. Consider how severe the problem is, when you get it and how frequently it happens. Please rate each item below on how bad it is (the amount of each problem). Because of my child’s voice, how much of a problem is this?
My child/ I has trouble speaking loudly or being heard in noisy situations.

name.en: Problem is “as bad as it can be”

question.en: Session ID

question.en: Questionnaire Duration (seconds)

lcq_chest_stomach_pains.description: Indicates if the participant experiences chest or stomach pains as part of their cough symptoms.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, have you had chest or stomach pains as a result of your cough?

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_sputum_phlegm.description: Indicates if the participant produces sputum or phlegm as part of their cough symptoms.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, have you been bothered by sputum (phlegm) production when you cough?

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_tired.description: Indicates if the participant feels tired due to their cough.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, have you been tired because of your cough?

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_embarrassed.description: Indicates if the participant feels embarrassed by their cough.

question.en: How often during the last 2 weeks have you felt embarrassed by your coughing?

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_anxious.description: Indicates if the participant feels anxious due to their cough.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, my cough has made me feel anxious.

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_interfere_job.description: Indicates if the participant's cough interferes with their ability to work.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, my cough has interfered with my job or other daily tasks.

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_interfere_life.description: Indicates if the participant's cough interferes with their daily life.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, I felt that my cough interfered with the overall enjoyment of my life.

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_exposure_paint.description: Indicates if the participant has been exposed to paint or chemical fumes that worsen their cough.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, exposure to paint or fumes has made me cough.

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_sleep.description: Indicates if the participant's cough affects their sleep.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, has your cough disturbed your sleep?

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_bout.description: Indicates if the participant has bouts of coughing.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, how many times a day have you had a coughing bout?

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_frustrated.description: Indicates if the participant feels frustrated as part of their cough symptoms.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, my cough has made me feel frustrated.

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_fed_up.description: Indicates if the participant feels fed up due to their cough.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, my cough has made me feel fed up.

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_hoarse_voice.description: Indicates if the participant has a hoarse voice as part of their cough symptoms.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, have you suffered from a hoarse voice as a result of your cough?

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_serious_illness.description: Indicates if the participant's cough interferes with their life due to a serious illness.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, have you worried that your cough may indicate serious illness?

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_other_people.description: Indicates if the participant feels that their cough bothers other people.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, have you been concerned that other people think something is wrong with you, because of your cough?

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_interrupt_conversation.description: Indicates if the participant's cough interrupts conversations.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, my cough has interrupted conversation or telephone calls.

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_partner.description: Indicates if the participant feels that their cough affects their partner or significant other.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, I feel that my cough has annoyed my partner, family, or friends.

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_felt_in_control.description: Indicates if the participant feels in control of their cough.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, have you felt in control of your cough?

name.en: A good bit of the time

lcq_energy.description: Indicates if the participant experiences low energy as part of their cough symptoms.

question.en: In the last 2 weeks, have you had a lot of energy?

name.en: A good bit of the time
